# !/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-


import json
import requests


def query(url):
    r = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
    result = json.loads(r.text)
    title = result['list'][0]['list'][0]['title']
    pubtime = str(result['list'][0]['list'][0]['viewDate'])
    if result['list'][0]['type'] == 79:
        link = xwzx_prefix + str(result['list'][0]['list'][0]['id'])
    else:
        link = aqdt_prefix + str(result['list'][0]['list'][0]['id'])
    bbs_name = result['list'][0]['list'][0]['sourceFrom']
    data = {
        "title":title,
        "pubtime":pubtime,
        "link":link,
        "bbs_name":bbs_name
    }
    return data

# !/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-


import time


nowtime = time.strftime('%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S GMT', time.localtime())


def send_message(url):
    result = query(url)
    time_now_ux = int(time.time())
    time_pub_ux = int(result['pubtime'])
    dev = time_now_ux - time_pub_ux
    if dev <= 1800:
        send(news)
        print(news)
    else:
        print(nowtime, "--*-- No news updated --*--")

package main
import (
"encoding/json"
"fmt"
"io/ioutil"
"net/http"
)
//å®šä¹‰jsonç»“æ„
type IPinfo struct {
  Code int `json:"code"`
  Msg string `json:"msg"`
  Data struct {
    IP string `json:"ip"`
    Country string `json:"country"`
    Province string `json:"province"`
    City string `json:"city"`
    County string `json:"county"`
    Region string `json:"region"`
    Isp string `json:"isp"`
  } `json:"data"`
}
func main() {
  ipquery := "42.193.103.52" //è¦æŸ¥è¯¢çš„IPåœ°å€
  url := "http://localhost:9090?ip="
  response, err := http.Get(url + ipquery)
if err != nil {
    fmt.Println("The site is down")
  } 
  body, _ := ioutil.ReadAll(response.Body)
var IP_Info IPinfo
  err = json.Unmarshal(body, &IP_Info)
if err != nil{
    fmt.Printf("The error is %+v 
", err)
  }
  fmt.Printf("The IP %v is from %v 

", IP_Info.Data.IP, IP_Info.Data.Country)
}

Dedicated to all the parents who try to explain software engineering to their children.

å†…å®¹ç®€å•ç”ŸåŠ¨ï¼Œèƒ½è®©äººå¾ˆå¥½çš„ç†è§£ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯Kubernetesï¼Œæˆ‘ç®€å•ç¿»è¯‘äº†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œå’Œå¤§å®¶åˆ†äº«ã€‚


Once upon a time there was an app named Phippy. And she was a simple app. She was written in PHP and had just one page. She lived on a hosting provider and she shared her environment with scary other apps that she didnâ€™t know and didnâ€™t care to associate with. She wished she had her own environment: just her and a webserver she could call home.


ä»å‰æœ‰ä¸ªåä¸ºPhippyçš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚å¥¹æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚å¥¹æ˜¯ç”¨PHPç¼–å†™çš„ï¼Œåªæœ‰ä¸€é¡µã€‚å¥¹ä½åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡æä¾›å•†é‚£é‡Œï¼Œå¹¶ä¸å…¶ä»–å¥¹ä¸çŸ¥é“å¹¶ä¸”ä¸æ„¿æ„ä¸ä¹‹å…³è”çš„å¯æ€•åº”ç”¨å…±äº«ç¯å¢ƒã€‚å¥¹å¸Œæœ›è‡ªå·±æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªè‡ªå·±çš„ç¯å¢ƒï¼šåªæœ‰å¥¹å’Œä¸€ä¸ªç½‘é¡µæœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œå¥¹å¯ä»¥æ‰“ç”µè¯å›å®¶ã€‚

An app has an environment that it relies upon to run. For a PHP app, that environment might include a webserver, a readable file system, and the PHP engine itself.


åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå…·æœ‰è¿è¡Œæ‰€ä¾èµ–çš„ç¯å¢ƒã€‚å¯¹äºPHPåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºï¼Œè¯¥ç¯å¢ƒå¯èƒ½åŒ…æ‹¬WebæœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œå¯è¯»æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿä»¥åŠPHPå¼•æ“æœ¬èº«ã€‚

One day, a kindly whale came along. He suggested that little Phippy might be happier living in a container. And so the app moved. And the container was nice, butâ€¦ It was a little bit like having a fancy living room floating in the middle of the ocean.


æœ‰ä¸€å¤©ï¼Œä¸€åªé²¸é±¼æ¥äº†ã€‚ä»–å»ºè®®ï¼Œå°Phippyå¯èƒ½ä¼šæ›´å¿«ä¹åœ°ç”Ÿæ´»åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå®¹å™¨ä¸­ã€‚è¿™æ ·åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå°±æ¬å®¶äº†ã€‚é‚£ä¸ªå®¹å™¨å¾ˆå¥½ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯â€¦â€¦æœ‰ç‚¹åƒæ˜¯ä¸€é—´è±ªåçš„èµ·å±…å®¤æ¼‚æµ®åœ¨å¤§æµ·ä¸­é—´ã€‚


A container provides an isolated environment in which an app, together with its environment, can run. But those isolated containers often need to be managed and connected to the external world. Shared file systems, networking, scheduling, load balancing, and distribution are all challenges.


å®¹å™¨æä¾›äº†ä¸€ä¸ªéš”ç¦»çš„ç¯å¢ƒï¼Œåœ¨å…¶ä¸­å¯ä»¥è¿è¡Œåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºåŠå…¶ç¯å¢ƒã€‚ä½†æ˜¯é‚£äº›å­¤ç«‹çš„å®¹å™¨é€šå¸¸éœ€è¦è¢«ç®¡ç†å¹¶è¿æ¥åˆ°å¤–éƒ¨ä¸–ç•Œã€‚å…±äº«æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œç½‘ç»œï¼Œè°ƒåº¦ï¼Œè´Ÿè½½å¹³è¡¡å’Œåˆ†å‘éƒ½æ˜¯æŒ‘æˆ˜ã€‚


The whale shrugged his shoulders. â€œSorry, kid,â€ he said, and disappeared beneath the oceanâ€™s surface. But before Phippy could even begin to despair, a captain appeared on the horizon, piloting a gigantic ship. The ship was made of dozens of rafts all lashed together, but from the outside, it looked like one giant ship.

â€œHello there, friend PHP app. My name is Captain Kubeâ€ said the wise old captain.


é²¸é±¼è€¸äº†è€¸è‚©è†€ã€‚â€œæŠ±æ­‰ï¼Œå­©å­ï¼Œâ€ä»–è¯´ï¼Œæ¶ˆå¤±åœ¨æµ·é¢ä¹‹ä¸‹ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯åœ¨Phippyç”šè‡³å¯èƒ½å¼€å§‹ç»æœ›ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œä¸€åèˆ¹é•¿å‡ºç°åœ¨åœ°å¹³çº¿ä¸Šï¼Œé©¾é©¶ç€ä¸€è‰˜å·¨å¤§çš„èˆ¹ã€‚è¿™è‰˜èˆ¹æ˜¯ç”±æ•°åæ ¹ç»‘åœ¨ä¸€èµ·çš„æœ¨ç­åˆ¶æˆçš„ï¼Œä½†ä»å¤–é¢çœ‹ï¼Œå®ƒå°±åƒä¸€è‰˜å·¨å‹èˆ¹ã€‚

â€œä½ å¥½ï¼ŒPHPåº”ç”¨æœ‹å‹ã€‚æˆ‘çš„åå­—å«Kubeèˆ¹é•¿ã€‚â€œèªæ˜çš„è€èˆ¹é•¿è¯´åˆ°ã€‚


â€œKubernetesâ€ is the Greek word for a shipâ€™s captain. We get the words Cybernetic and Gubernatorial from it. The Kubernetes project focuses on building a robust platform for running thousands of containers in production.


â€œ Kubernetesâ€æ˜¯å¸Œè…Šè¯­ä¸­çš„èˆ¹é•¿ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ä¸­å¾—åˆ°äº†æ§åˆ¶è®ºå’Œå·é•¿ä¸€è¯ã€‚Kubernetesé¡¹ç›®ä¸“æ³¨äºæ„å»ºä¸€ä¸ªå¼ºå¤§çš„å¹³å°ï¼Œä»¥åœ¨ç”Ÿäº§ä¸­è¿è¡Œæ•°åƒä¸ªå®¹å™¨ã€‚


â€œIâ€™m Phippy,â€ said the little app.

â€œæˆ‘æ˜¯Phippyï¼Œâ€å°åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè¯´ã€‚

Kubernetes uses labels as â€œnametagsâ€ to identify things. And it can query based on these labels. Labels are open-ended: You can use them to indicate roles, stability, or other important attributes.


Kubernetesä½¿ç”¨æ ‡ç­¾ä½œä¸ºâ€œåç§°æ ‡ç­¾â€æ¥è¯†åˆ«äº‹ç‰©ã€‚å®ƒå¯ä»¥åŸºäºè¿™äº›æ ‡ç­¾è¿›è¡ŒæŸ¥è¯¢ã€‚æ ‡ç­¾æ˜¯å¼€æ”¾å¼çš„ï¼šæ‚¨å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨å®ƒä»¬æ¥æŒ‡ç¤ºè§’è‰²ï¼Œç¨³å®šæ€§æˆ–å…¶ä»–é‡è¦å±æ€§ã€‚


Captain Kube suggested that the app might like to move her container to a pod on board the ship. Phippy happily moved her container inside of the pod aboard Kubeâ€™s giant ship. It felt like home.


Kubeèˆ¹é•¿å»ºè®®ï¼Œè¯¥åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¯èƒ½å¸Œæœ›å°†å…¶å®¹å™¨ç§»åŠ¨åˆ°èˆ¹ä¸Šçš„åŠèˆ±ä¸­ã€‚Phippyé«˜å…´åœ°å°†è‡ªå·±çš„å®¹å™¨ç§»åˆ°äº†Kubeçš„å·¨å‹èˆ¹ä¸Šçš„åŠèˆ±ä¸­ã€‚æ„Ÿè§‰å°±åƒå®¶ã€‚


In Kubernetes, a Pod represents a runnable unit of work. Usually, you will run a single container inside of a Pod. But for cases where a few containers are tightly coupled, you may opt to run more than one container inside of the same Pod. Kubernetes takes on the work of connecting your pod to the network and the rest of the Kubernetes environment.


åœ¨Kubernetesä¸­ï¼ŒPodè¡¨ç¤ºå¯è¿è¡Œçš„å·¥ä½œå•å…ƒã€‚é€šå¸¸ï¼Œåœ¨Podå†…è¿è¡Œä¸€ä¸ªå®¹å™¨ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œå¯¹äºå‡ ä¸ªå®¹å™¨ç´§å¯†è€¦åˆçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥é€‰æ‹©åœ¨åŒä¸€Podå†…è¿è¡Œå¤šä¸ªå®¹å™¨ã€‚Kubernetesè´Ÿè´£å°†ä½ çš„Podè¿æ¥åˆ°ç½‘ç»œä»¥åŠKuberneteså…¶ä»–ç¯å¢ƒçš„å·¥ä½œã€‚


Phippy had some unusual interests. She was really into genetics and sheep. And so she asked the captain, â€œWhat if I want to clone myselfâ€¦ On demandâ€¦ Any number of times?â€

â€œThatâ€™s easy,â€ said the captain. And he introduced her to the replication controllers.

â€œé‚£å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“ï¼Œâ€èˆ¹é•¿è¯´ã€‚ç„¶åï¼Œä»–å‘å¥¹ä»‹ç»äº†å¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨ã€‚

Replication controllers provide a method for managing an arbitrary number of pods. A replication controller contains a pod template, which can be replicated any number of times. Through the replication controller, Kubernetes will manage your podsâ€™ lifecycle, including scaling up and down, rolling deployments, and monitoring.


å¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨æä¾›äº†ä¸€ç§ç”¨äºç®¡ç†ä»»æ„æ•°é‡çš„Podçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨åŒ…å«ä¸€ä¸ªPodæ¨¡æ¿ï¼Œè¯¥æ¨¡æ¿å¯ä»¥è¢«å¤åˆ¶ä»»æ„æ¬¡ã€‚é€šè¿‡å¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨ï¼ŒKuberneteså°†ç®¡ç†æ‚¨çš„Podçš„ç”Ÿå‘½å‘¨æœŸï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬æ‰©å¤§å’Œç¼©å°ï¼Œæ»šåŠ¨éƒ¨ç½²å’Œç›‘è§†ã€‚


For many days and nights the little app was happy with her pod and happy with her replicas. But only having yourself for company is not all itâ€™s cracked up to beâ€¦. even if it is N copies of yourself.

Captain Kube smiled benevolently, â€œI have just the thing.â€

No sooner had he spoken than a tunnel opened between Phippyâ€™s replication controller and the rest of the ship. With a hearty laugh, Captain Kube said, â€œEven when your clones come and go, this tunnel will stay here so you can discover other pods, and they can discover you!â€

Kubeèˆ¹é•¿ä»æ…ˆåœ°ç¬‘äº†ç¬‘ï¼Œâ€œæˆ‘æœ‰ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚â€

ä»–åˆšå¼€å£è¯´è¯å°±åœ¨Phippyçš„å¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨å’Œèˆ¹çš„å…¶ä½™éƒ¨åˆ†ä¹‹é—´æ‰“å¼€äº†ä¸€æ¡éš§é“ã€‚åº“ä¼¯èˆ¹é•¿ç¬‘ç€è¯´ï¼šâ€œå³ä½¿ä½ çš„å…‹éš†æ¥æ¥å»å»ï¼Œè¿™æ¡éš§é“ä¹Ÿä¼šç•™åœ¨è¿™é‡Œï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ‚¨å°±å¯ä»¥å‘ç°å…¶ä»–podsï¼Œä»–ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥æ‰¾åˆ°ä½ ï¼â€


A service tells the rest of the Kubernetes environment (including other pods and replication controllers) what services your application provides. While pods come and go, the service IP addresses and ports remain the same. And other applications can find your service through Kurbenetes service discovery.


æœåŠ¡ä¼šå‘Šè¯‰Kubernetesç¯å¢ƒçš„å…¶ä½™éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬å…¶ä»–Podå’Œå¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨ï¼‰ä½ çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºæä¾›ä»€ä¹ˆæœåŠ¡ã€‚å½“Podæ¥æ¥å¾€å¾€æ—¶ï¼ŒæœåŠ¡IPåœ°å€å’Œç«¯å£ä¿æŒä¸å˜ã€‚å…¶ä»–åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡KurbenetesæœåŠ¡å‘ç°æ¥æ‰¾åˆ°ä½ çš„æœåŠ¡ã€‚


Thanks to the services, Phippy began to explore the rest of the ship. It wasnâ€™t long before Phippy met Goldie. And they became the best of friends. One day, Goldie did something extraordinary. She gave Phippy a present. Phippy took one look and the saddest of sad tears escaped her eye.

â€œWhy are you so sad?â€ asked Goldie.

But Goldie knew what to do. â€œWhy not put it in a volume?â€

A volume represents a location where containers can access and store information. For the application, the volume appears as part of the local filesystem. But volumes may be backed by local storage, Ceph, Gluster, Elastic Block Storage, and a number of other storage backends.

Phippy loved life aboard Captain Kubeâ€™s ship and she enjoyed the company of her new friends (every replicated pod of Goldie was equally delightful). But as she thought back to her days on the scary hosted provider, she began to wonder if perhaps she could also have a little privacy.

â€œIt sounds like what you need,â€ said Captain Kube, â€œis a namespace.â€

A namespace functions as a grouping mechanism inside of Kubernetes. Services, pods, replication controllers, and volumes can easily cooperate within a namespace, but the namespace provides a degree of isolation from the other parts of the cluster.


å‘½åç©ºé—´ç”¨ä½œKuberneteså†…éƒ¨çš„åˆ†ç»„æœºåˆ¶ã€‚æœåŠ¡ï¼Œpodï¼Œå¤åˆ¶æ§åˆ¶å™¨å’Œå·å¯ä»¥åœ¨åç§°ç©ºé—´å†…è½»æ¾åä½œï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åç§°ç©ºé—´æä¾›äº†ä¸ç¾¤é›†å…¶ä»–éƒ¨åˆ†ä¸€å®šçš„éš”ç¦»åº¦ã€‚


Life was good aboard Captain Kubeâ€™s boat. Together with her new friends, Phippy sailed the seas. She had many grand adventures, but most importantly, Phippy had found her home.

And so Phippy lived happily ever after.
